description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5484d","text":"Flow charts can be used in human, animal and in vitro studies, as well as systematic reviews, to illustrate attrition or loss of observation. Flow charts provide a visual overview of the study design, and detailed information about the number of included and excluded observations at each stage of the experiment or study, as well as reasons for exclusion. This information is essential to evaluate the risk of bias, and also helps other investigators to estimate the resources that would be needed to perform similar studies. Despite these advantages, few studies have flow charts. Some templates for designing flow charts are available (e.g. CONSORT template for clinical trials, PRISMA template for systematic reviews), however these templates are designed for specific study designs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":644,"length":36},{"key":1,"offset":682,"length":38}],"data":{}},{"key":"5q1cj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bne2b","text":"Output: This protocol allows readers to efficiently design a flow chart for their study. The protocol is designed to work for many different study designs. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fo5j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"930bp","text":"Expertise: Scientists using this protocol will need software for making flow charts, detailed knowledge of their study design and detailed study documentation (see last sentence of materials, below). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1nr7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"v8g2","text":"Materials: Scientists will need a software program that they are comfortable with, which allows them to design flow charts (e.g. Power Point, LucidChart). A calculator is helpful to confirm that the numbers in the flow chart add up. If the study is in progress or has been completed, scientists will need data on the number of included and excluded observations at each complete stage of the study to include in the flow chart. This information can be added later for studies that are in progress. Other specific expertise is not required.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C0EC67504EBC11EDAC467D8459388171","url":"https://www.consort-statement.org/consort-statement/flow-diagram"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"EC3DBA804EBC11EDAC467D8459388171","url":"https://prisma-statement.org/prismastatement/flowdiagram.aspx"}}}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"f65ab","text":"This protocol may not work for every study design or research area.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"b93fk","text":"This is designed to be a general protocol that will work for many types of study designs. Outlining your flow chart on paper to establish the structure before adding details in the software program can save you time.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70snj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25qnq","text":"Users who are conducting clinical trials may wish to consult the template in the CONSORT guidelines. Users who are conducting systematic reviews or meta-analyses may wish to use the template in the PRIMSA guidelines instead.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"b4up8","text":"Software for designing flow charts (e.g. power point, LucidChart, etc.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fnjb","text":"Tip: Outline your flowchart on paper first to set the structure, then fill in details using the software. This saves time.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g64e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"afar9","text":"Calculator (to confirm that numbers add up)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnq2s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fvvr","text":"Detailed knowledge of study design","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"72hni","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"83qvc","text":"If the study is in progress or completed, users will need data for the number of included and excluded observations at each completed stage of the experiment, and the reasons for exclusion.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":67,"length":121}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Scenario 1: Design a flow chart for a study with many steps and one group
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"akkdt","text":"State the number of included observations in each box (n = x)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d85ti","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c30uq","text":"Tips","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfs8j","text":"Clearly describe what x represents. Be specific. Replace vague terms like “animals” or “participants” with more specific terms like “Sprague Dawley rats”, “brain slices from Bl6 mice”, or “healthy men and women”.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5sh4t","text":"Don’t use the term “patients”. This term can refer to humans in clinical studies, or animals in veterinary studies. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0tlv","text":"Don’t forget to include a sample size in the first box. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kkbn","text":"Specify sex or gender: After showing the total sample size, consider presenting a breakdown by sex or gender. Example: n = 12 Sprague Dawley rats (6 M, 6 F). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23},{"style":"bold","offset":110,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51gjb","text":"If your experimental unit differs from the number of participants, samples, or animals assessed, specify this. Instead of “(n = x)”, write (N = x experimental units, n = x individuals). Replace the words “experimental unit” and “individual” with specific terms for your study.                                              ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":110}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46uhc","text":"            Example 1: Cages of mice were randomized to a treatment or placebo. Describe your sample size as “(N = 5 cages, n = 10 mice).”                                            ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":12,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fhdk","text":"            Example 2: Doctor’s offices were randomized to treatment or placebo. All patients within the practice were assigned to the same group. Describe your sample size as “(N = 10 practices, n = 5,623 patients).”                                           ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":12,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"518b3","text":"            Example 3: 3-5 brain slices were selected from each mouse. Describe your sample size as “(N = 10 mice, n = 43 brain slices).”","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":12,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1j9s6","text":"If your observational or experimental unit changes at different phases of your study, clearly note this. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":105}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e3kdd","text":"           Example: You start by harvesting cells from human participants. You then conduct studies on cultured cells. At the sample collection phase, your units may be “n = 5 patients”. At later phases, your units may be “n = 5 6-well plates.”","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":11,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19mi7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1mdim","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1q33","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8okjt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B5A947A0293C11ED8960AF45769CA5FC","height":309,"id":345166,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Clin_study_included_n.JPG","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcsbcvcx.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcqbcvcx.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcrbcvcx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcpbcvcx.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"72748E8029C911ED9D9851AE7C531402","height":412,"id":345170,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"MR_flowchart_incl_n.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcwbcvcx.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcubcvcx.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktcvbcvcx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktctbcvcx.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.section: Scenario 1: Design a flow chart for a study with many steps and one group
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dm9i4","text":"Add numbers and reasons for exclusions: Below the “Excluded” title, list all reasons for exclusion. Next to each reason, list the number of excluded observations during that phase. Example: “Lost to follow-up: n = 2”, “Not enough sample collected: n = 1”. This information will help readers to determine which exclusions may be a source of bias, and which are unlikely to contribute to bias.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"for87","text":"Be specific about your reasons for exclusion. Replace vague terms like “technical failure” with specific explanations like “FACS machine not working: n = 2 plasma samples”.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5286r","text":"Avoid grouping participants into broad categories when more specific information is available. For example, instead of stating “Withdrew: n = 10”, specify “Withdrew due to side effects: n = 3”, “Withdrew due to time commitment: n = 5”, “Withdrew for unknown reasons: n = 2.” Caution: This may not be possible for large studies, however you should avoid grouping reasons for exclusion that are a potential source of bias with those that are not.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":93},{"style":"bold","offset":275,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dpikc","text":"Specify sex or gender: After showing the total sample size, consider presenting a breakdown by sex or gender. Example: n = 12 Sprague Dawley rats (6 M, 6 F). Define all abbreviations. Note: There are tradeoffs to using abbreviations. Abbreviations shorten the text inside boxes, but make it challenging for readers to interpret the flow chart. The same abbreviation can mean very different things in different fields. Eye movements back and forth between the figure and legend are time consuming and frustrate readers, especially for large figures with many abbreviations or figures where the legend is placed on a different page. Consider these tradeoffs when deciding whether to use abbreviations and how many abbreviations to use. Abbreviations should generally be used sparingly for small flow charts, but may be necessary for large, complex flow charts.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1n2st","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7q7hl","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d3n5k","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d6thh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"35B32470293D11ED8960AF45769CA5FC","height":309,"id":345198,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1vcdk","text":"Figure 1: Identification of women with end stage renal disease through records linkage","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7l4ec","text":"Medical records from the Rochester Epidemiology Project were linked with records from the United States Renal Data System to identify women who had end stage renal disease. steps.section: Scenario 2: Design a flow chart for a study with many groups
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"56ckg","text":"Label group boxes: Title each box with the group name, followed by “(n = x)”. Replace x with the number of patients, samples or animals included in that group at that phase of the study. If your group name doesn’t clearly describe your unit of observation, describe your unit of observation after “(n = x)” (example: n = x Sprague Dawley rats). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bfg1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cbe3v","text":"Tips","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ce2v","text":"Don’t forget to label the first box and include the sample size. If your first stage is about screening and observations haven’t been assigned to groups yet, the group name should specify the population studied (e.g. “Bl6 mice (n = 50)”, “healthy pregnant women, \u003c12 weeks gestation (n = 79)”.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":63}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88a9a","text":"Group names should clearly specify what was done to the group, or inclusion criteria for the group. Avoid vague names like “Group 1”, “Control group”, “Case group” or “Treatment group.”","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":98}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2h337","text":"The “units” should clearly specify what was observed. Replace vague terms like “animals” or “participants” with more specific terms like “Sprague Dawley rats”, “brain slices from Bl6 mice”, or “healthy men and women”.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ccktr","text":"Don’t use the term “patients”. This term can refer to humans in clinical studies, or animals in veterinary studies. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80so","text":"Specify sex or gender: After showing the total sample size, consider presenting a breakdown by sex or gender. Example: n = 12 Sprague Dawley rats (6 M, 6 F). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23},{"style":"bold","offset":110,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52ia6","text":"Avoid abbreviations when possible. They make the flow chart hard to read and different abbreviations mean different things in different fields.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkbcf","text":"If your experimental unit differs from the number of participants, samples, or animals assessed, specify this. Instead of “(n = x)”, write (N = x experimental units, n = x individuals). Define all abbreviations. Note: There are tradeoffs to using abbreviations. Abbreviations shorten the text inside boxes, but make it challenging for readers to interpret the flow chart. The same abbreviation can mean very different things in different fields (Google your abbreviations to make sure that they are commonly known). Eye movements back and forth between the figure and legend are time consuming and frustrate readers, especially for large figures with many abbreviations or figures where the legend is placed on a different page. Consider these tradeoffs when deciding whether to use abbreviations and how many abbreviations to use. Abbreviations should generally be used sparingly for small flow charts, but may be necessary for large, complex flow charts.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hfmi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74o9k","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8hifb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8A699090295011ED9D9751AE7C531402","height":309,"id":345226,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"49v5e","text":"Figure x: Study flow chart","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"329kt","text":"This flow chart illustrates the flow of mice trough this preclinical study. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7d6ag","text":"Explain why you planned to do this ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"566ni","text":"Explain how you selected participants, samples or animals in which to perform the measurement.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ee48","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7k3v9","text":"Example: When designing the study, we planned to perform measurement 30 out of 60 randomly selected samples. This measurement is expensive and we did not have sufficient funding to analyze all samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7q5r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dg958","text":"Rationale: When assessing the risk of bias, it is important to differentiate between situations were you planned to perform measurements in a subset of participants, animals or samples, and situations where this decision was made after the study began or due to excluded samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe7ql","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4acu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"4267BF10B44211EDA847076A5125946A","height":314,"id":345250,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cltoi","text":"*Placental analyses were performed in two randomly selected placentas from each litter, in accordance with our pre-planned study protocol, to limit study costs.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Flowchart_Protocol_Scenario2_3.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktfebcvcx.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktfcbcvcx.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktfdbcvcx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktfbbcvcx.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"du7dp","text":"Scenario 4: You have too many groups to show in a flow chart","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jkq2","text":"Use a table instead, showing groups in columns and study stages in rows. Use sub-columns for each group to enter the number of included and excluded observations and reasons for exclusion. Consider color coding cells for excluded observations. The colors won't be machine readable, but they will allow human readers to quickly visually identify groups and stages with higher exclusion rates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
